name: Letter from Edward Harcourt, Draycott, to Walter Bagot?
description: Asks Bagot to intercede to prevent the sending of Burche's son, since Burche and his wife are old and depend upon the son for their living.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Edward Harcourt, Draycott, to Walter Bagot
description: Asks help for John Walker, who has been injured by one Battkin so that he will never for his senses be his own man; it is reported that Bagot is a favorer of Battkin's, and that makes him the bolder.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Richard Harcourt to Walter Bagot
description: Asks for a lieutenant's place under Mr. Digby or whoever else takes Crompton's (Crumpton's) captaincy.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Sir Walter Harcourt, Stanton Harcourt, to Walter Bagot
description: Thanks for favor shown to him rather than to Bagot's brother-in-law, Richard Broughton. Hopes soon to make such satisifaction that neither Bagot nor Broughton shall be sorry, and hopes soon to wade out of this labyrinth of debt and danger.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Sir Walter Harcourt to Walter Bagot
description: Understands that Mr. Basset intends to serve an elegit on him and on Sir Edward Littleton, surety for his (Harcourt's) debt to Basset. This will be served in open court, and if Bagot (the sheriff) does not execute the writ there is a remedy against him. Suspects a plot between Basset and Littleton. Hopes to raise money in the city.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Sir Walter Harcourt, Ellenhall (Ellnall), to Walter Bagot
description: By sale of land he is now able to pay off debts of 3,000 and give 1,000 to his daughter Elizabeth. Asks Bagot (sheriff) to tell him where the writs for the election of the knights of the shire will be held; some of his friends are working for him, but this is none of his doing.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Sir Walter Harcourt, Ellenhall, to Walter Bagot
description: Is grateful for forbearance over the debt, but takes unkindly Bagot's putting him in mind of promises he never forgot and importuning him for payment. Asks Bagot to let him know (even if a messenger ride all night) as soon as the writs for the elections come.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Sir Walter Harcourt to Walter Bagot
description: Has reason to suspect false measures; would be informed whether Bagot has the writs for the election and whether he plans to call it before next county day; he is determined to stand to prevent disgrace. Asks to be told the matter of Bagot's and Mr. Skeffington's talk about him.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Sir Walter Harcourt, Shareshill?, to Walter Bagot
description: Bagot now having the writ, he supposes he will hold the election as usual. It is rumored that Harcourt will not stand or that if he does exception will be taken because of the judge's charge; but there is nothing in this, and it is doubtful that the proclamation January 11, 1603/04 is lawful calling for knights of good ability. Asks Bagot's help for William Shawe, in gaol.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Sir Walter Harcourt, Ellenhall, to William Trew
description: Is grieved and hurt; thought Bagot's and Trew's friendship meant more, but accepts the fact. Asks Trew to meet him by the pool dam at eight o'clock next day; wants to know executions Bagot (sheriff) has, and at whose suit.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Sir Harvey Bagot, Oxford, to Walter Bagot
description: In Latin. Acknowledges his father's love and generosity and promises every effort to excel in his work. Accompanied by Latin theses and poetry.

name: Letter from Sir Walter Harcourt, Ellenhall, to Walter Bagot
description: Is deeply grateful for Bagot's willingness to wait for payment, but will pay at the fixed time. Asks Bagot to have his servants deliver to Harcourt's daughter a token (of some value) from her mother and to tell his son Harcourt that Bagot is satisfied.

name: Letter from Sir John Harpur, Swakeston, Derbyshire, to Walter Bagot
description: Is sending a draft of an answer to Sir Anthony Ashley's bill, for Bagot to alter, approve, and return; he will send it to Mr. Egerton; sends also a copy of the bill and documents from Lady Ashley concerning Heywood and Findern Farm Derbyshire.

name: Letter from Sir John Harpur, Swakeston, to Walter Bagot
description: Is sending documents mentioned in his previous letter which his man then forgot to bring. A notation by Bagot concerns a house at Findern, sold to Philip Okeover and Jane, Lady Ashley, by Sir Thomas Gresham of Asterley.

name: Letter from Sir John Harpur, Swakeston, to Walter Bagot
description: For stealing steers John Ashcroft is bound to appear at Stafford assizes, but has fled to Lathom, Lancs. Asks Bagot to write to some justice there to have him apprehended and returned, so that Harpur's tenant, Nicholas Roberts, who is surety for Ashcroft's appearance, will not forfeit.

name: Letter from Sir Christopher Hatton, Drayton, to Richard Bagot
description: Has received Bagot's letter and the prisoners he sent; commends Bagot for his loyal and energetic activity.

name: Letter from Sir Christopher Hatton, the Court at Richmond, to Richard Bagot and Thomas Gresley
description: One William Sawforde complains of being wrongly deprived of certain lands and tenements; Bagot and Gresley to examine into the cause and either resolve it in Sawforde's favor or certify Hatton as to the equities of it.

agent.name: Sir Christopher Hatton, the Court at Richmond

name: Letter from Richard Heathe to Walter Bagot
description: Asks for an appointed time to discuss with Bagot the goods of his cousin Mary Jones. An endorsement in Bagot's hand reads: Wood spent in the glasshouse 418.di.

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Sir Thomas Heneage, The Savoy, to Richard Bagot and Sir Edward Aston
description: Ralph Adderley has entered suit against a poor man named John Ashton over a cottage in the Forest of Needwood; Bagot and Aston to examine the merits of the case and resolve it in Ashton's favor or make a report. Signed also by Sir John Brograve. An endorsement calls the plaintiff Chr. Aston.

agent.name: Richard Bagot and Sir Edward Aston

name: Letter from J. Herbert and William Aubrey, Hampton Court, to Sir Edward Littleton, Sir Edward Aston, and Richard Bagot
description: Anthony Kynnersley is accused of unconscionable dealing against an unnamed man and one Lewis Warter; the addressees to examine the parties and resolve the dispute or bind them to appear before the Court of Requests.

agent.name: J. Herbert and William Aubrey, Hampton Court
Sir Edward Littleton, Sir Edward Aston, and Richard Bagot

name: Letter from Martin Heton, Winchester, to Richard Bagot
description: Certain persons having complained of the marriage of Katherine Lowe to Anthony Bagot instead of to Simon Weston, Heton asks Bagot to make it appear to the world that she is well bestowed upon A. Bagot; he says he was chiefly instrument in the marriage.

name: Letter from Sir Harvey Bagot, Oxford, to Walter Bagot
description: Has repaid to Mr. Throgmorton the money lent to Humphrey when the latter was robbed.

name: Letter from Walter Hamersley to Walter Bagot
description: Asks Bagot to press Hamersley's father to transfer some piece of property to him and so assure him of a living after his father's decease.

name: Letter from Walter Hamersley, Oxford, to Walter Bagot
description: Asks Bagot to persuade Hamersley's father to sign and seal the deed.

name: Letter from William Hopkin, London, to Thomas Haughton, Haughton
description: There will be a change soon; will send a message when this occurs. Also, another cryptic letter to John Haughton at Haughton from Henry Jones, London, February 13, 1595/96. There will be a change soon and things will be better. Haughton's captain prays he may be able to requite all of his friends. Has met Haughton's brother at court. The above are copies of the two letters sent by Richard Bagot to Lord Burghley (see L.a.84).

name: Letter from John Hunt, St. John's, to Walter Bagot
description: Castlehayes (Castell Haye) not worth more concern, for Powell has a good patent from Sir Robert Brett. The trial delayed by the Lord Chancellor's illness; he not expected to recover; many seek the office. The king at Newmarket.

name: Letter from John Hunt, Newtown, to Walter Bagot
description: Mr. Halford's commission is to be at Leicester on the 14th; Bagot's presence urged; his signature and Sir Thomas Wolseley's required on a warrant; to defeat the plaintiff's cunning will require care.

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

name: Letter from Richard Hunte, Shrewsbury, to Walter Bagot
description: Has been unable to get the friezes ordered, but will get them soon at Oswestry market; received the 6 and the cloths to pack the friezes in.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Jeffry? Hurleston to Walter Bagot
description: It lies in the discretion of the ordinary to grant administration of the estate of Richard Bagot, d. February 2 to the relict or to her and a son, and the ordinary will oversee the administration.

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

name: Letter from Henry Jackson, Stanshope (Stansop), to Walter Bagot
description: Lists amounts paid to Mr. Leigh for repairs to the hanging bridge; all but 40s. is disbursed; if Salt, the bearer, does not bring more money, the work will stop. At bottom of sheet Bagot lists the amount owing, Hundred by Hundred.

name: Letter from James I, King of England to the Chief Justices and justices of assize
description: Collectors of a benevolence for Dorchester, lately burnt, to be appointed. John Gray, goldsmith in Cheapside, to receive the funds. A note by Bagot says that 12, 6 shillings have been sent. Gray's receipt, October 31, 1614, is laid in. The body of the letter is a copy. See L.a.141.

agent.name: the Chief Justices and justices of assize

name: Letter from W. Johnson, Paddington, to Walter Bagot
description: His sister, Margaret Houell, is not dead, but is in good health and like to live long; he saw her in Norfolk lately. Asks Bagot to remind Mr. Arblaster that he looks for his money on the day and will stick to the bond.

name: Letter from Sir Harvey Bagot, Oxford, to Walter Bagot
description: The 10 sent to Mr. President was delayed. A note of expenses enclosed. Two public plays at Trinity College.

name: Letter from W. Johnson, Wanstead, to Walter Bagot
description: Understands that his brother Johnson has made an agreement by which he will get the 30 three years overdue from Thomas Arblaster; feels grieved and is the loser; will not brook further delay.

name: Letter from W. Johnson, Wanstead, to Walter Bagot
description: By the death of his sister Margaret Houell his brother John Johnson is a heavy loser. Reminding Bagot of his promise to be good to Johnson's father's children, he prays for renewal of the lease for three lives at the same rent.

name: Letter from John Jones (clerk) to Walter? Bagot
description: The bearer has been defrauded by Bagot's new tenant, Nichols, who refused to vacate the mill at Kynton Water and then left it in a ruinous state.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from R. Karr, the Court at Whitehall, to Walter Bagot
description: Correspondent possibly Robert Kerr, Earl of Lothian, a Master of Requests. Thomas Clarke, Bagot's poor neighbor, having broken the law received the king's pardon. Nevertheless Bagot's people malign him so that he fears for his life. Asumes Bagot's knowledge of this and demands his interference.

agent.name: R. Karr, the Court at Whitehall

name: Letter from Thomas Kemys, Chartley, to Walter Bagot
description: The Earl of Essex wishes Bagot and Sir Simon Weston to open any letters that come to him from the Privy Council during his absence and to have regard for his Majesty's service.

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

name: Letter from John Kenrick, Waldinges?, to Walter Bagot (Deputy Lieutenant)
description: Has collected the required 25 for the mustermaster and for supplies - a contribution for the crown; has collected 25 shillings from each of 25 divisions. Sends list of contributors and defaulters.

name: Letter from John Kenrick, Waldinges?, to Walter Bagot
description: Has met resistance in collecting for Bridgeford Bridge and the defense of Willaston's suit; has not sent the money because those who gave want their money back if the others do not give.

name: Letter from Thomas Kery, London, to Walter Bagot
description: Means are made, through Mr. Fortescue, for the release of Mr. Reynolds, of Stoke. It would be wise not to press him for payment.

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

name: Letter from Ralph Kettell, Trinity College, Oxford, to Walter Bagot
description: Is glad to have Walter's son Harvey living with him, also young Broughton. Their tutor will be satisfied if Bagot sends him quarterly a mark for Harvey and a pound for Broughton.

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

name: Letter from Ralph Kettell, Oxford, to Walter Bagot
description: Bagot's treatment of Mr. Votier the tutor has been appreciated; he is not to think ill of young Thomas Broughton because of his hasty coming. Bagot's sons are showing promise; everything possible will be done for them.

name: Letter from Sir Harvey Bagot, Oxford, to Walter Bagot
description: The 10 shillings for his sheep and 10 shillings more receive from Mrs. Beardmore. A note of expenses enclosed. Has sent for stuff for a gown to be made in Oxford, where they are better made than in London. Mr. President proposes that Harvey leave Oxford for the Inns of Court.

name: Letter from Ralph Kettell, Oxford, to John Chadwick
description: Discusses in general terms a suit in which is involved with an unnamed adversary. He will not arbitrate.

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Alexander King, Auditor of the Exchequer, to Richard Bago
description: Warns Bagot to come or send to an audit to be held at Wolverhampton in October to settle his reckoning for his receipts from Ensore out of the iron works at Bromley. Broughton has several times failed to attend to this matter.

agent.name: Alexander King, Auditor of the Exchequer

name: Letter from Roger Knight to Walter Bagot
description: Cannot find the boyes indenture and asks favor.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Thomas Kniveton, Mercaston, to Richard Bagot?
description: Lady Shrewsbury (his sister-in-law) lately bought Barleston Manor, Leicestershire from Lord Stafford, and then found that it was encumbered with debts and statutes now extendable and in Bagot's hands. Asks extension. Asks if Bagot knows a man named Townsend who might know about Stafford's debts.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Sir William Kniveton, Mercaston, to Walter Bagot
description: Has received Bagot's letter about his earlier motion concerning Bagot's son (i.e., his marriage), and will continue in every way to perform the offices of a kinsman and friend.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile

name: Letter from Sir Francis Knollys, the Court, to Sir Walter Aston and Richard Bagot, sheriff
description: Thanks them for their faithfulness in protecting the land, servants, and tenants of the Earl of Essex, and urges them to continue this needful office.

agent.name: Sir Walter Aston and Richard Bagot, sheriff

name: Letter from Sir Francis Knollys, Richmond, to Robert, Earl of Essex
description: Points out the young earl's poverty and reprimands him for lavish spending for followers and equipment for his expedition to the Low Countries. (Copy in R. Bagot's hand; printed in W.B. Devereux, Lives and letters of the Devereux, Earls of Essex..., 1853, I, 178-179.)

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Anthony Kynnersley, Loxley, to Walter Bagot
description: The order of Bagot and cousin Aston was broken by Lowe, not by Mrs. Aston. Lowe carried off over twenty thraves of corn not assessed, after his lease expired. Mrs. Aston found the door of the house open and took quiet possession. If Bagot supports Lowe and punished Mrs. Aston he will be doing injustice.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Anthony Kynnersley, Loxley, to Walter Bagot
description: When he sent to his wicked son Francis for his money his son had just received 40, but told the servant that he was not on such terms with his father as to send him money. And he said his father should neither sell wood nor land from Badger, and bade him make the most of his feoffment, and said he wished to have his child away from his father. If Bagot sends for the child he shall have him. In future he will be more careful how he bestows his love. The answer to L.a.120.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Anthony Kynnersley, Loxley, to Walter Bagot
description: Has received complaint that Ellen Chatfield, who was hired and covenanted for three years to serve Mr. Edmund Rudyard, the preacher, has left and is said to be at Blithfield. Asks that she be returned or at least turned out. See See L.a.768.

name: Letter from Sir Harvey Bagot, Oxford, to Walter Bagot
description: Gile's son (from Tixall) to be poor scholar to Biddulph. Asks that money be sent him. Mr. Nevill proceeded B.A. in royal sort.

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Anthony Kynnersley, Loxley, to Walter Bagot
description: Has heard that Edward Mastergent has made clamorous speeches, calling him and his cousin Aston two-penny and three-penny justices and saying that poor innkeepers were forced to contribute to buy the justices' dinners.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Anthony Kynnersley, Loxley, to Harvey Bagot
description: Is amazed that Bagot failed to keep his promise and send those two brethren Ashes with sureties for their good behavior; urges his doing so at once.

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Anthony Kynnersley, Loxley, to Walter Bagot
description: The widow Sisley Smith, a recusant, demised her estate to her son Thomas, she to receive money and lodging. Through fraudulent dealing of another son, she received no money. The evidences were written under a hedge. Kynnersley has often been generous to her.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Anthony Kynnersley, Uttoxeter, to Walter Bagot
description: Understanding that Bagot had bought the bailiffship of Totmonslowe Hundred, he sent to ask if he would sell half to Kynnersley and received word that he would. Asks confirmation, expresses thanks, promises requital.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Anthony Kynnersley, Loxley, to Walter Bagot?
description: Asks Bagot to send over a certain commission, that he may study it. Had thought only those who held by knight's service or socage could serve on the commission, and now fears that he has done a disservice to his tenants at Dilhorne, Caverswall (Carswall), and Forsbrook, who hold of him as chief lord.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Anthony Kynnersley, Loxley, to Walter Bagot
description: Will lease a tenement to Mr. York, of London, either for 21 years or three lives; or will sell woods or lands, if it can be arranged that all proceeds will go to pay his debts. Wants to leave this world without harming any man.

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Francis Kynnersley to Walter Bagot
description: Will not live at Bramshall (Broomshall); will settle nowhere but Loxley or Badger.
